question: Is higher exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) associated with increased prevalence of anxiety symptoms in adults? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: CONCLUSIONS Exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) was associated with high symptoms of anxiety, with more recent exposures potentially more relevant than more distant exposures.
content.source_2: After adjustment for demographic and lifestyle covariates, higher PM2.5 showed no relation to anxiety prevalence across multiple averaging windows; per 10 µg/m3 increase in the prior one-month and 12-month averages, adjusted odds ratios were 0.99 (95% CI 0.93 to 1.05) and 1.01 (0.93 to 1.10), respectively.
content.source_3: Significantly increased odds of high anxiety symptoms were observed with higher exposure to PM2.5 for multiple averaging periods (for example, odds ratio per 10 µg/m(3) increase in prior one month average PM2.5: 1.12, 95% confidence interval 1.06 to 1.19; in prior 12 month average PM2.5: 1.15, 1.06 to 1.26).
content.source_4: In a population-based cohort, there was no evidence that recent or longer-term PM2.5 exposure was associated with anxiety; the dose–response was flat and estimates clustered around the null (e.g., prior 12-month average: OR 0.96, 95% CI 0.88 to 1.05), with sensitivity analyses yielding similar conclusions.
